pros: OK place to get some experience.  Tons of dayshift openings due to retirements and high turnover.  2nd and 3rd shift seem to have a much better atmosphere than 1st shift.
cons: Pay for techs is low (not unique to Pittsburgh as a whole).  Vacation accrual also occurs very slowly.  Parking is expensive and you are not guaranteed to get a permit near the lab for literally years.  Management very lackadaisical about essentially everything.  Lots of problems that they just don't seem interested in adjusting.  Turnover is a big problem, but they do nothing to try to help (more flexible scheduling, increase in pay - literally, nothing).  Coworkers on day shift tended to be very cliquey and racist.  Every lunch break involved listening to racist tirades.  Only way to get a break from it was to eat lunch somewhere else besides the only break room in the building. Management didn't seem to care.  Not a good place for new grads - really seems to be a place where anyone with any sense of ambition leaves, quickly.

review_title: Any call center veterans, PLEASE READ before proceeding
job_title: Care Connect Elite Representative (Scheduling) in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: descent pay for call center, good benefits. As
cons: My heart wants to say that from an operations standpoint, and a workforce standpoint, they are behind the times. But that's not even correct, the truth is, this call center is run totally off the wall vs any other you may have worked in. The center is broke up in to three tiers, which for the (small) size, is ridiculous. In tier 3, we are in que 5 days a week. No exaggeration. You get your head beat in 5 days a week in tier 3, taking calls of all kinds, and then you get a transfer from either tier 1 or tier 2 to cancel an appointment, which is so easy, my 8 year old could do it. You wait 2-3 days for time off approval (i'm used to no more than an hour wait). You are not given any time off up front, you accrue time (five hours every pay period). You have only one bank of personal time, and although we are all working from home now, when in office, most people come to work sick because they don't want to waste their time off. My first vision of being in the office was all of the reps who had cold medicine bottles on their desks. Most of the high level superiors have no background in call center, although our new director does. We will see how that goes. If you are like me, one reason I have stayed in call center work for so long is, despite the industry you are working in, the specific job is always different, but call center life is generally virtually the same, no matter what industry you are in. Here's the biggest exception ever.

review_title: Elite Care Connect Representative - Call Center
job_title: Elite Care Connect Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: The positions at the call center have reasonable compensation for the average college student or young adult looking for a foot-in-the-door at a decent company.  The instructors and trainers offer a very thorough training system that proves very effective prior to entering full "production." The office care committee does try to make it as friendly as possible by hosting holiday celebrations, celebrating birthdays, and providing employee appreciation days/weeks. The office is very sports friendly and offers dress down days frequently. Co-workers are very friendly and it is a very social environment. The company offers a very nice healthcare package at a very reasonable rate. The company also offers a tuition program that will reimburse you for Federal School loans after 10 years because it is a non-profit company. The customers offices that we work with are very friendly and truly understand the benefit of the work we are doing.  For such a young call center, the department is growing fast.
cons: Unfortunately beyond the training and appreciation days, that only seem to take the edge off of how expendable they treat their employees, the department is extremely lacking in several areas. After initial training, there is no consistency  within management as far as expectations, quality control, and employee appreciation.  Management does try to push promotion and upward mobility within the department, however they make several false promises along the way. The "Elite" position, as it's called, usual is paired with a unreasonable shift for anyone with a family or social life. Management often tells employee's to "try it out" and if it doesn't work out they can change shifts, positions, etc. This simply is not the case, once you are in a position they will keep you there as long as it benefits them, with no recognition for how it affects the employee. Which is simply that is just bad business ethics. As far as flexibility with Paid Time Off (PTO) requests, the company does offer great PTO packages, that you will never use in this department. You can never have Monday's off, unless it is part of a full week request. If you try to request the full week , good luck, because it isn't available. Management is usual happy to negotiate a day that would work best for both parties... 6 months down the road.  The only way you get time off is by calling off, which costs you points, on their "points system." The people that have worked there since the beginning of the call center, do get treated reasonably. Everyone else however, not exactly. A lot of the management within the center are extremely under qualified, or have no clue how to do the job they are supervising. They we're simply hired based on management ability at other companies. The knowledge aspect of their job is left to their team leads, who are usually wonderful by the way. (No sarcasm, I truly mean that... great job guys)

pros: Close to where I live and it's not UPMC.  I do think the individuals in the company do a good job treating patients.
cons:
For the past 7 years I've been downstaffed significantly on a regular basis.  Just when I think I'll finally be able to get the hours I was hired for we're downstaffed for weeks at a time again.  To add insult to injury I don't even know when I'm coming in to work until the day before and I don't know when I'm going to be sent home from work until minutes before I'm sent home.  Some weeks I've had as little 12 hours.    

When we actually get busy I'm obligated to work past the end of my work shift, in violation of PA Act 102, which jeopardizes my husband's job as he can't leave our child until I'm home.  If other AHN sites need help I'm required to go to them no matter how far away they are and I'm certainly not paid for the time it takes to get to these sites.  There is also no consideration given for how much longer it takes me to get home; if I have to drive 90 minutes after the end of my shift my husband will, once again, be late for his job.  What I've been told is that if I don't go it's the same as a "No call, no show."  

There is also no consistency in setting or enforcing rules as to who is downstaffed or who is sent where.  One day we're taking turns - until someone management likes complains.  Then the "rules" are turned inside out to make sure the "squeaky wheel" gets what they want - as long as you're liked.  Promotions are non-existent unless you've worked closely with senior management.  The culture is unfair and abusive.  The attitude is that one should be happy to have a job, so shut up.  Add in that there is no 403b match, raises are small, and the benefits are expensive and this is not a place I would recommend to anyone who isn't willing to be treated like they're worthless.

review_title: Leaving felt so so so good.
pros: Worked remotely 2 days a week. Some really great co-workers.
cons:
I started and they didn't have a desk for me and another women starting the same time. We sat in a conference room from 9-5 for two weeks. It was awkward and boring and did not feel appreciated. I should have known from the start this is how it would be.

There was also a strange animosity in the department, an "us vs them" scenario. Employees that had been there a long time did not like the new Supervisor and in return were dismissive and cold to new employees hired by the new manager. Which was fine, I wasn't hurt by it and in return I was closer to "newer" hires. But it seemed very childish and created a slightly stressful environment.

The department was on a tight budget and was run by 'inexperienced" management and so my work load was extremely high, in other words unmanageable with very very very little support from higher up.

There was a lot of speaking badly about others and backstabbing by hire-ups, which of course trickles down to the department. Lots of finger pointing. Everyone just seemed extremely unhappy. There was a lot of turn-over, including people quitting, going to other departments, and lay-offs.

All in all I did not look forward to going to work everyday, I basically put my head down did my work and applied for jobs at night. 

I had 3-4 supervisors in less than a year, from leads to managers to directors, just turning over.
